author: _._nx_._
content: Hi there. I am just starting with ePBS. I wonder if there were any updates on RPC auction rules? Specifically, will multiple bids be allowed and will cancellations be allowed via this channel? I know that P2P channel is public one bid first price auction, but I have not found any decisions like that for the private RPC channel. Cheers!

author: potuz
content: The expected implementation is to request a signed bid directly on the HTTP endpoint. There can't be any cancellation since the proposer is not trusted. Vanilla clients won't request multiple bids from the same builder, but nothing prevents forked clients on doing so, or even promisse cancellations.

author: _._nx_._
content: Thank you for the clarification!

author: potuz
content: notice that cancellations don't really make sense on a pull system

author: _._nx_._
content: Can you expand on this? Is this because the nature of the auction changed to private one-bid/n-bid first price?

author: potuz
content:
Cancellations make sense if you push bids to the relay, and keep updating them until eventually the proposer requests a bid and the relay only serves the latest updated one. 

In ePBS, builders are their own relays, the proposer will only request once. The builder can serve right then at that moment the best it has. It didn't need to be pushing intermediate bids at no point. If the proposer requests again another bid, the builder cannot trust it that it will cancel the first one, since it's already signed.

author: _._nx_._
content: That makes perfect sense. So even if the builder saw an opportunity to cancel (as in sudden external market change), they cannot cancel in this protocol because the proposer cannot be trusted to respect their cancellation. Do I understand correctly? And then I guess multiple bids can still make sense as long as the bids go higher in time, because the proposer will choose the highest bid either way.

author: potuz
content: There's no time to see a an oportunity, as soon as the builder serves the bid the proposer will broadcast the block with it

author: potuz
content: There will be no delay between the bid generation and the block propagation, at least not with vanilla clients

author: _._nx_._
content: What about time when the proposer chooses the builder? Itâ€™s settled beforehand and served at the beginning of the slot, with no continuity?

author: _._nx_._
content: I see. Interesting. Is it considered to be continuous beyond vanilla?

author: potuz
content: I don't understand the question

author: _._nx_._
content: As in, is it not possible even for a very short time for a builder to observe, say, existing p2p bids and bid higher than the rest? In other words, can a builder delay bidding for a potential advantage

author: potuz
content: The builder is requested  a bid, it cannot delay, there's a deadline to the request, and that's as much as the builder can "delay"

author: _._nx_._
content: Makes perfect sense. Thank you for taking the time to explain :))

author: dapplion
content:
Small suggestion: https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/pull/4736

It's possible that a DataColumnSidecars arrives before the beacon block it's referencing. We don't yet how builders / users will use Gloas and publish things. To prevent instability, the spec should suggest to cache DataColumnSidecars the same way we cache attestations and aggregates for unknown beacon blocks.
